commands.explanation: This command is used to initialize a new repository. It creates the dot git directory, which contains all the necessary metadata. This is establishing the foundation, for version control in your project.
This is defined as the repository duplication command. It is creating a complete copy, of a remote repository, onto your local system. All history and branches, are transferred during this process.
This command is referred to as the staging operation. It is placing modified files, into the staging area. The staging area is preparing changes, for the next commit.
This is commonly known as the snapshot command. It is recording the staged changes, into the repository history. Each commit creates a permanent record, with a unique identifier.
This command is defined as the state inspector. It is showing the current condition, of your working directory. Modified files, staged files, and untracked files, are all displayed here.
This is referred to as the upload command. It is transferring your local commits, to a remote repository. The remote repository is being updated, with your latest changes.
This command is commonly known as the synchronization operation. It is fetching changes from a remote repository. Those changes are then being merged, into your current branch.
This is defined as the branch management command. It is listing all existing branches, in your repository. When given a name, it is creating a new branch, at the current commit.
This command is referred to as the branch switcher. It is moving your working directory, to a different branch. Files in your workspace, are being updated to match, the target branch.
This is commonly known as the integration command. It is combining changes from different branches. The histories are being woven together, into a unified timeline.
This command is defined as the history viewer. It is displaying the commit history, for your repository. Each entry shows the author, the date, and the commit message.
This is referred to as the comparison tool. It is showing the differences, between various states of your code. Line by line changes, are being highlighted for review.
This command is commonly known as the undo operation. It is moving the current branch pointer, to a different commit. The staging area, can also be modified by this command.
This is defined as the safe undo command. It is creating a new commit, that reverses previous changes. The history remains intact, with this approach.
This command is referred to as the temporary storage operation. It is saving your uncommitted changes, in a hidden area. Your working directory, is being returned to a clean state.
This is commonly known as the download command. It is retrieving commits from a remote repository. Unlike pull, it is not merging anything automatically.
This command is defined as the connection manager. It is listing all configured remote repositories. You can add, remove, or rename these connections.
This is referred to as the marker command. It is creating a named reference, to a specific commit. Tags are often used, for release versions.
This command is commonly known as the detail viewer. It is displaying information, about a specific commit. The changes introduced, are being shown in full.
This is defined as the removal command. It is deleting files, from your working directory. Those files are also being removed, from version control.
This command is referred to as the rename operation. It is moving or renaming files, within your repository. Git is tracking this change, as a rename rather than a deletion.
This is commonly known as the settings command. It is managing your Git configuration options. User name, email, and preferences, are all controlled here.
This command is defined as the history rewriter. It is moving commits, to a new base. The commit history, is being reorganized for clarity.
This is referred to as the selective merge command. It is applying specific commits, from one branch to another. Only the chosen changes, are being transferred.
This command is commonly known as the workspace cleaner. It is removing untracked files, from your directory. The working area, is being restored to a pristine state.
This is defined as the annotation command. It is showing who modified each line, of a file. The commit and author information, are displayed for every line.
This command is referred to as the search tool. It is looking for patterns, within your tracked files. Text matching, is being performed across the entire repository.
This is commonly known as the reference log viewer. It is displaying a history, of where your branches have pointed. Even deleted commits, can be found here.
This command is defined as the bug finder. It is using binary search, to locate problematic commits. The process is narrowing down, which change introduced an issue.
